results.title: Darling Darling
results.creator_credit: Gabriella Hirst, Sam Smith and Bridget Ikin
results.credit_line:
Gabriella Hirst
Two-channel video installation, digital video, sound, 25:30 mins.
SanDisk Memory Card, gold leaf, in collaboration with Barbara Dabrowa, AGNSW Senior Conservator of Fine Arts – Frames
Courtesy the artist
Ian Potter Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection
results.material_description: Two-channel video installation, digital video, sound and gilded SD card
results.brief_description:
Darling Darling presents two contrasting but linked responses to the idea of conservation. One side of the screen shows the meticulous care taken to restore WC Piguenit’s prized 1895 painting of the Barka-Darling River, The flood in the Darling, 1890, while the other side reveals the present-day neglect of the river itself. Excess upstream water diversion and climate change have contributed to severe water scarcity and mass fish kills in recent years.

In composing her shots of the river, Hirst references Australia’s beloved landscape painting tradition, and colonial-era artists like Eugene von Guérard, John Glover, Conrad Martens, Nicholas Chevalier, Ludwig Becker and of course, WC Piguenit. While their romantic paintings capture a sense of nature as awe inspiring, they also served the more material purpose of framing resources to be owned and exploited by European settlers, a visual expression of the concept of terra nullius.

Darling Darling invites us to question the role played by Western visual art traditions in shaping the value systems that allow such an extreme environmental crisis to unfold right before our eyes.

Gabriella Hirst (she/her) is an artist. She was born and grew up on Cammeraygal land (Australia) and is currently living between Berlin and London. She works primarily with moving image, performance, and with the garden as a site of critique and care. Gabriella’s practice and research explores connections between various manifestations of capture and control – spanning plant taxonomies, landscape painting, art conservation and nuclear history.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gabriella Hirst, Sam Smith and Bridget Ikin

results.title: Magic lantern slipping slide (Le nez d'arlequin - the harlequin's nose)
results.brief_description: Hand painted magic lantern slipping slide ‘Le Nez d’Arlequin’ -‘ The Harlequin’s Nose’ or ‘Punch with Long Nose’ with wooden frame. Manufactured by E.Mazo, Paris. By moving the slipping slide, a harlequin’s nose grows longer and three small children appear on the tip. The words ‘Punch’s Long Nose’ is etched vertically in to the glass plate.

results.title: Magic lantern set effects slide (Man and lions)
results.brief_description: Magic lantern set effects slide with wooden frame. By sliding the effects slide, a man fights between two lions set against a black background. Made by Lawler, 161 Strand, London. ‘91’ written in pencil on wooden frame. Cream tape has been adhered to the edge of the sliding section.

results.title: Sony Handycam DCR-SX65
results.brief_description: The Sony Handycam DCR-SX65 debuted in 1985 and while other models from the era have been discontinued, it’s been made in various formats ever since. Home videos might have been their original purpose, but camcorders like this have captured footage that has social and political ramifications.

constellations_primary.name: A handheld aesthetic
constellations_primary.description: Looking at the use of handycams and other consumer level devices in moving image works.

results.description: The Sony Handycam DCR-SX65 is what it says: it’s a handy camera. Debuting on the market in 1985, its name came from its compact size that allowed it to fit in the user’s hand and capture their everyday lives more easily. While other models from this era have been discontinued, the Sony Handycam DCR-SX65’s popularity has seen it made in various formats ever since. Home videos might have been their original purpose, but their cost and convivence meant camcorders like this have been used to capture amateur footage that has social and political ramifications all around the world.
description_for_label: The Sony Handycam DCR-SX65 is what it says: it’s a handy camera. Debuting on the market in 1985, its name came from its compact size that allowed it to fit in the user’s hand and capture their everyday lives more easily. While other models from this era have been discontinued, the Sony Handycam DCR-SX65’s popularity has seen it made in various formats ever since. Home videos might have been their original purpose, but their cost and convivence meant camcorders like this have been used to capture amateur footage that has social and political ramifications all around the world.

results.title: We Dream of Networks
results.credit_line:
Jess Johnson
Limited edition print
ACMI Collection
results.material_description: giclée print on archival quality cotton rag with four deckled edges, edition 40/50
results.brief_description:
Jess Johnson was born in Aotearoa/New Zealand in 1979, and lives and works in New York. Her drawing and installation practice is influenced by science fiction, language, culture and technology. In her drawings she depicts complex worlds that combine densely layered patterns, objects and figures within architectural settings. Johnson’s drawings are often displayed within constructed environments that act as physical portals into her speculative worlds. Her video collaborations with Simon Ward have involved translating her drawings into animated Virtual Reality, thus enabling her audience to have the simulated experience of entering the hypnotic realms depicted in her drawings. Jess Johnson’s work has been exhibited Internationally in solo exhibitions at; Jack Hanley Gallery, New York; Art Basel, Hong Kong; Nanzuka Gallery, Tokyo; Talbot Rice Gallery, Edinburgh; National Gallery of Australia; Museum of Contemporary Art, Australia; Auckland Art Gallery and Christchurch Art Gallery, New Zealand.

Jess Johnson is represented by Darren Knight Gallery, Sydney; Ivan Anthony Gallery, Auckland and Jack Hanley Gallery, New York

results.title: Model 621 Sound Projector with tripod and stand
results.credit_line: ACMI Collection. Tripod donated by Daryl Annett.
results.brief_description: In 1951, this projector was brought to the Koomooloo Station in South Australia to entertain workers during the shearing season.

constellations_primary.name: Bell & Howell Projector 621: This picture has been edited for content
constellations_primary.description: The Bell & Howell-Gaumont Model 621 projector was originally used entertain the shearers on a sheep farm in South Australia with the films screened sometimes edited for distribution.

results.title_for_label: Model 621 Sound Projector with tripod and stand
results.description: Though it was made in England, this projector made it over 15,000kms to the Koomooloo Station in South Australia. Situated on pastoral land in the Murray and Mellee region of South Australia, Koomooloo Station operated as a sheep station from 1868 and in 1951, this projector was bought to entertain workers during the shearing season. Luckily it has a vent at the back of the casing to keep it cool because if it was used inside a shearing shed the heat would’ve been insufferable.
description_for_label: Though it was made in England, this projector made it over 15,000kms to the Koomooloo Station in South Australia. Situated on pastoral land in the Murray and Mellee region of South Australia, Koomooloo Station operated as a sheep station from 1868 and in 1951, this projector was bought to entertain workers during the shearing season. Luckily it has a vent at the back of the casing to keep it cool because if it was used inside a shearing shed the heat would’ve been insufferable.
results.credit_line_for_label: ACMI Collection. Tripod donated by Daryl Annett.
